claim: People smoke more on average in the United States than in Russia.

supporting.text: According to the World Health Organization, the prevalence of smoking among adults in the United States is higher than in Russia.

attacks.text: According to the World Health Organization, the prevalence of smoking among adults in the United States is higher than in Russia.
The WHO data may not account for differences in data collection methods between the two countries, potentially skewing the comparison.
The WHO standardizes data collection protocols across countries to ensure comparability, minimizing methodological biases.
Cultural differences in self-reporting smoking habits could lead to underreporting in Russia, making the comparison unreliable.
Studies using biochemical validation (e.g., cotinine tests) confirm self-reported smoking rates in Russia are broadly accurate.

supporting.text: The United States has a higher per capita cigarette consumption compared to Russia, as reported by global health statistics.

attacks.text: The United States has a higher per capita cigarette consumption compared to Russia, as reported by global health statistics.
The data might not account for unrecorded tobacco consumption, which is higher in Russia due to informal markets and homemade tobacco products.
Even accounting for informal markets, official statistics still show a significant gap in per capita consumption favoring the U.S., suggesting the trend holds.
Cultural differences in reporting and data collection methods between the U.S. and Russia could skew the comparison.
International health organizations standardize data collection methods to ensure comparability across countries, minimizing such biases.

supporting.text: Public health campaigns and tobacco control policies in Russia have been more stringent in recent years, leading to lower smoking rates than in the United States.

attacks.text: Public health campaigns and tobacco control policies in Russia have been more stringent in recent years, leading to lower smoking rates than in the United States.
The smoking rate in Russia remains higher than in the U.S. due to cultural acceptance and historical tobacco use patterns.
Recent WHO data shows a decline in Russian smoking rates, supporting the effectiveness of their policies.
U.S. smoking rates have also declined significantly due to widespread anti-smoking campaigns and regulations.
The decline in U.S. smoking rates has plateaued in recent years, while Russia's decline has been more consistent.

supporting.text: Cultural attitudes toward smoking in the United States have historically been more permissive, contributing to higher average smoking rates.

attacks.text: Cultural attitudes toward smoking in the United States have historically been more permissive, contributing to higher average smoking rates.
Recent anti-smoking campaigns and regulations in the United States have significantly reduced smoking rates, potentially making them lower than in Russia.
Russia has also implemented strict anti-smoking laws in recent years, which may have reduced smoking rates there as well.
Cultural attitudes in Russia have traditionally been more accepting of smoking, which could still result in higher smoking rates there despite recent changes.
Studies show that smoking rates in Russia remain high due to lower public awareness of health risks compared to the United States.

supporting.text: Data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and Russian health ministries show that the percentage of daily smokers is greater in the United States than in Russia.

attacks.text: Data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and Russian health ministries show that the percentage of daily smokers is greater in the United States than in Russia.
The data may not account for differences in reporting methodologies between the CDC and Russian health ministries, potentially skewing the comparison.
Both the CDC and Russian health ministries follow internationally recognized standards for data collection, minimizing methodological discrepancies.
The data might not include informal or unrecorded tobacco use, which could be higher in Russia due to cultural practices.
